Knowledge Point: When overt, core arguments and adjuncts are located before the verb. In (\ref{ex:RnaRna.YAsindZi}) for instance, the intransitive subject \forme{ɯ-mu ɯ-wa ni} `his mother and his father' (§\ref{sec:dyads}) in the dual is placed before the adverb \japhug{ʁnaʁna}{both} and the main verb \forme{ɲɤ-si-ndʑi} `they_{du} died'. The dual suffix on the verb here indexes the number of the intransitive subject (§\ref{sec:intr.23}).
Content 1: \gll [ɯ-mu ɯ-wa ni] ʁnaʁna ɲɤ-si-ndʑi | \gls 3SG.POSS-mother 3SG.POSS-father du both IFR-die-DU | \glt `His parents had both died.'

Knowledge Point: In the case of semi-transitive verbs (§\ref{sec:semi.transitive}), which have two absolutive arguments, it is very rare to have both an overt intransitive subject and an overt semi-object (except if the semi-object is a complement clause, see §\ref{sec:complement.clause.case.marking}). The semi-object can be follow (\ref{ex:kWkWra.YWrganW}) or precede (\ref{ex:pGa.ra.mArganW}) the subject, but in the second case there is a pause, indicative of left dislocation.
Content 1: \gll kɯkɯra <xuexiao> ɲɯ-rga-nɯ. | \gls DEM.PROX:PL school SENS-like-PL | \glt `Those (the children) like school.'
Content 2: \gll tɤɕi nɯ, pɣa ra nɯstʰi mɤ-rga-nɯ. | \gls barley DEM bird PL that.much NEG-like:FACT-PL | \glt `The barley, the birds don't like it so much.'

Knowledge Point: With intransitive verbs selecting a locative phrase (§\ref{sec:intr.goal}), the locative phrase is generally located between the intransitive subject and the verb (\ref{ex:SOblV}).
Content 1: \gll [ɯ-pi ni] tʂu kɯ-wxti nɯtɕu jo-ɕe-ndʑi | \gls 3SG.POSS-elder.sibling DU road SBJ:PCP-be.big DEM:LOC IFR-go-DU | \glt `His two elder brothers went [along] the big road.'

Knowledge Point: However, it is possible to put the locative phrase before the subject, especially when it refers to the source of the motion (§\ref{sec:motion.verbs}), as in (\ref{ex:OblSV}) and (\ref{ex:OblSV2}).
Content 1: \gll tɯmɯnɤmkʰa nɯtɕu [qro χsɯm] pjɯ-ɣi-nɯ | \gls heaven DEM:LOC pigeon three IPFV:DOWN-come-PL | \glt `(Every day), three pigeon came down from heaven.'
Content 2: \gll mtsʰu ɣɯ ɯ-ŋgɯ nɯtɕu [mtsʰoʁlaŋ] to-nɯ-ɬoʁ | \gls lake GEN 3SG.POSS-in DEM:LOC water.monster IFR-AUTO-come.out | \glt `A water monster came out of the lake.'

Knowledge Point: Oblique phrases with the relator noun \japhug{ɯ-taʁ}{on, above} selected by the main verb (§\ref{sec:WtaR}) are located between the intransitive subject and the verb, as in (\ref{ex:tArAku.WtaR.wuma.pe}) and (\ref{ex:ZmbrW.WtaR.karindZi}).\footnote{
Content 1: \gll [ɯ-ɣli nɯ] li tɤ-rɤku ɯ-taʁ wuma ʑo pe | \gls 3SG.POSS-dung DEM again INDEF.POSS-crop 3SG.POSS-on really EMPH be.good:FACT | \glt `Its dung is good (as fertilizer) for the crops.'
Content 2: \gll tɕendɤre [ʑɤni pɣa ni] ʑmbrɯ ɯ-taʁ kɤ-ari-ndʑi ɲɯ-ŋu. | \gls lnk 3DU bird DU boat 3SG.POSS-on AOR:EAST-go[II] SENS-be | \glt `The two of them [including the bird] departed on the boat.'

Knowledge Point: With the motion verb \japhug{ɕe}{go}, in (\ref{ex:ZmbrW.WtaR.karindZi}) in stem II \forme{ari}, \forme{ɯ-taʁ} specifically indicates the means of transportation (§\ref{sec:WtaR}). }
Content 1: \gll tɕendɤre [ʑɤni pɣa ni] ʑmbrɯ ɯ-taʁ kɤ-ari-ndʑi ɲɯ-ŋu. | \gls lnk 3DU bird DU boat 3SG.POSS-on AOR:EAST-go[II] SENS-be | \glt `The two of them [including the bird] departed on the boat.'

Knowledge Point: Unlike intransitive subjects, essive adjuncts (§\ref{sec:essive.abs}) are closer to the verb than oblique arguments, as shown by \japhug{tɯrme}{person} in (\ref{ex:ataR.tWrme.penW}), which is not an intransitive subject (`the people are nice to me') but an essive phrase `as people' (see also \ref{ex:tWGli.Wuma.Zo.pe}, §\ref{sec:essive.abs}).
Content 1: \gll tɕe <zhoujikong> tɕe mɤʑɯ li a-taʁ tɯrme pe-nɯ ma | \gls LNK center.for.disease.control LNK even.more again 1SG.POSS-on person be.good:FACT-PL LNK | \glt `At the district center for disease control, they are also very nice to me (as people).'
Content 2: \gll tsʰɤt nɯ ɣɯ ɯ-ɣli nɯnɯ tɤ-rɤku ɯ-taʁ tɯ-ɣli wuma ʑo pe. | \gls goat DEM GEN 3SG.POSS-manure DEM INDEF.POSS-crops 3SG.POSS-on INDEF.POSS-manure really EMPH be.good:FACT | \glt `Goat manure is very good as a fertilizer for the crops.'

Knowledge Point: When the main verb is transitive, the transitive subject (with the ergative postposition, §\ref{sec:A.kW}) is found before the direct object (in absolutive form, §\ref{sec:absolutive.P}), as in (\ref{ex:SOV.pjAmtonW}).
Content 1: \gll kɯ-ɣɤrʁaʁ nɯra kɯ qartsʰaz ɯ-pɯ nɯ pjɤ-mto-nɯ | \gls SBJ:PCP-hunt DEM:PL ERG deer 3SG.POSS-little DEM IFR-see-PL | \glt `The hunters saw the little deer.'

Knowledge Point: The object of a transitive verb only rarely precedes the subject, except for object complement clauses (§\ref{sec:complement.word.order}), and examples exhibiting this order are all analyzable as left-dislocated topicalized constituents, as in (\ref{ex:OSV.thanWtsWm}).
Content 1: \gll a-tɕɯ, ji-rɣa ra nɯ-mbala kɯ tʰa-nɯtsɯm tɕe nɯnɯ ɯ-kɯ-ɕar ɕe-tɕi | \gls 1SG.POSS-son 1PL.POSS-neighbour PL 3PL.POSS-ox ERG AOR:3\fl{}3-AUTO-take.away LNK DEM 3SG.POSS-SBJ:PCP-search go:FACT-1DU | \glt `My son_i, the neighbour's ox has taken him_i away, and we are looking for him_i.'

Knowledge Point: In (\ref{ex:OSV.pjAndo}), the object \forme{ɯ-mpʰɯz nɯnɯ} is topicalized, and in addition the ergative phrase \forme{tɤjpɣom kɯ} is not a real agent.
Content 1: \gll ɯ-mpʰɯz nɯnɯ tɤjpɣom kɯ pjɤ-ndo | \gls 3SG.POSS-buttocks DEM ice ERG IFR-take | \glt `(The leopard's) buttocks had been caught in the ice.'

Knowledge Point: The object-subject-verb order is however found to focalize the subject, together with a postverbal copula (§\ref{sec:focalization.final.copula}) as in (\ref{ex:OSV.janWtsWm}), where the transitive subject \forme{nɯnɯ kɯ} follows the object (Chunjie).
Content 1: \gll <chunjie> \textbf{nɯnɯ} \textbf{kɯ} ja-nɯ-tsɯm ŋu tʰaŋ | \gls ANTHR DEM ERG AOR:3\flobv{}-VERT-take.away be:FACT SFP | \glt `It is probably him who took away Chunjie.'

Knowledge Point: Note that without intonation, (\ref{ex:OSV.janWtsWm}) is ambiguous, as [<chunjie> \forme{nɯnɯ kɯ}] could also be analyzed as a single constituent (since personal names can optionally take demonstrative determiners, §\ref{sec:personal.names.modifiers}), and in this case the translation of the sentence would be `Chunjie probably took him.' The above translation however is the correct one in the context of the story.
Content 1: \gll <chunjie> \textbf{nɯnɯ} \textbf{kɯ} ja-nɯ-tsɯm ŋu tʰaŋ | \gls ANTHR DEM ERG AOR:3\flobv{}-VERT-take.away be:FACT SFP | \glt `It is probably him who took away Chunjie.'

Knowledge Point: The recipient (direct object) generally precedes the theme (semi-object) of secundative verbs (§\ref{sec:ditransitive.secundative}) as in (\ref{ex:WRi.tWmgo.YAmbi}).
Content 1: \gll ɯ-ʁi tɯmgo ɲɤ-mbi | \gls 3SG.POSS-younger.sibling food IFR-give | \glt `He gave food to his younger brother.'

Knowledge Point: In noun-verbs collocations where the verb is secundative such as \forme{tɯ-nɯ+jtsʰi} `breastfeed' as in (\ref{ex:WpW.tWnW.Yjtshi}), placing the recipient (\forme{ɯ-pɯ}) after the them (\forme{tɯ-nɯ}) is never attested.
Content 1: \gll ɯ-pɯ tɯ-nɯ ɲɯ-jtsʰi kɯnɤ ʑo | \gls 3SG.POSS-young INDEF.POSS-breast IPFV-give.to.drink also EMPH | \glt `Even when [the monkey mother] nurses her baby,...'

Knowledge Point: However, with the verb \japhug{mbi}{give} there are examples of the opposite order as in (\ref{ex:kWlAG.nW.nambi}), where the theme (\forme{qajɣi kɤ-kɯ-ɕke nɯra} `pieces of bread that had burnt') precedes the recipient (\forme{kɯ-lɤɣ nɯ} `the shepherd').
Content 1: \gll tɕʰeme nɯ kɯ qajɣi kɤ-kɯ-ɕke nɯra kɯ-lɤɣ nɯ na-mbi | \gls girl DEM ERG bread AOR-SBJ:PCP-burn DEM:pl SBJ:PCP-herd DEM AOR:3\flobv{}-give | \glt `The girl gave the shepherd pieces of bread that had burnt (to eat).'

Knowledge Point: Causative derivations from transitive verbs have a causee (§\ref{sec:causee.kW}), whose syntactic status is intermediate between subject and object: it can be marked with the ergative, but is indexed as if it were an object if it is first or second person while the object is third person (§\ref{sec:ditransitive.causative}). The causee in the ergative is normally placed before the object (\ref{ex:Wmbro.kW.pjAzrAtCaR}), even when it serves as instrument (§\ref{sec:sig.caus.instrumental}) as in (\ref{ex:ZmbrWBJaj.kW.tuwGsWCmi}).
Content 1: \gll ɯ-mbro kɯ qapri tɯ-rdoʁ nɯ pjɤ-z-rɤtɕaʁ | \gls 3SG.POSS-horse ERG snake one-piece DEM IFR-CAUS-trample | \glt `He made his horse trample one of the [two] snakes.'
Content 2: \gll ``ʑmbrɯ-βɟaj nɯnɯ kɯ cʰa nɯ tú-wɣ-sɯ-ɕmi tɕe cʰa mɯm" tu-ti-nɯ pɯ-ŋu ma | \gls boat-oar DEM ERG alcohol DEM IPFV-INV-CAUS-mix LNK alcohol be.tasty:FACT IPFV-say-PL PST.IPFV-be LNK | \glt `People used to say that if one mixes the alcohol [using] a boat oar, it is tasty.'

Knowledge Point: The object can be located before the causee, but it is always a left dislocated constituent, followed by a pause as \forme{ɯ-ɕnɤz nɯnɯ} `its head/extremity' in (\ref{ex:WmtChi.kW.kusWndAm}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In the case of causative verbs from semi-transitive verbs (§\ref{sec:semi.transitive.causative}), such as \japhug{sɤrmi}{give a name} (from \japhug{rmi}{be called}, §\ref{sec:sig.caus.irregular.other}), the direct object (the person to whom a name is given) is always located before the semi-object (the name given), as in (\ref{ex:ndZitCW.tosArminW}).

Knowledge Point: Dative arguments (§\ref{sec:dative}) of indirective verbs (§\ref{sec:ditransitive.indirective}) follow the transitive subject as in (\ref{ex:kW.WCki.object}).\footnote{For reason of place, the theme (the reported speech clause) is not reproduced here and simply indicated by (...), but corresponds to example (\ref{ex:pWtWnWGenW.nWtCu} in §\ref{sec:aor.temporal}). }
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Dative phrases can be located either after the theme or before it, as shown by examples (\ref{ex:tAtsxu.WCki}) and (\ref{ex:WCki.tAtsxu}) redundantly describing the same action in the same story.
Content 1: \gll <alading> nɯ kɯ, nɤkinɯ, iɕqʰa tɤtʂu nɯ [ɯ-mu ɯ-ɕki] ɲɤ-kʰo tɕe, | \gls ANTHR DEM ERG FILLER the.aforementioned lamp DEM 3SG.POSS-mother 3SG.POSS-DAT IFR-give LNK | \glt `Aladin gave the lamp to his mother.'
Content 2: \gll [ɯ-mu ɯ-ɕki] tɤtʂu nɯ ɲɤ-kʰo. | \gls 3SG.POSS-mother 3SG.POSS-DAT lamp DEM IFR-give | \glt `He gave his mother the lamp.'

Knowledge Point: The first pattern (object-dative) is rarer than the second one, but attested for all indirective verbs, including verbs of speech, as in (\ref{ex:O.ndZiphe}), where the reported speech clause occurs before the dative phrase (compare with \ref{ex:kW.WCki.object} above, the more common pattern).

Knowledge Point: Most oblique arguments also follow the subject and precede the object. It is the case of the goal argument marked by the relator \forme{ɯ-taʁ} (§\ref{sec:WtaR}) in (\ref{ex:kW.WtaR.object}).
Content 1: \gll kɯ-ɣɤrʁaʁ kɯ [pri ɯ-taʁ] tɯdi to-lɤt | \gls SBJ:PCP-hunt ERG bear 3SG.POSS-on arrow IFR-release | \glt `The hunter shot an arrow at the bear.'

Knowledge Point: Non-overt core arguments, including subjects and objects, are always definite, and anaphorically refer to a previously mentioned entity. For instance, example (\ref{ex:tandza}) with a bare verb necessarily means `S/he/it ate it', and cannot be interpreted as `S/he/it ate/had a meal' with indefinite object or as `someone ate it' with indefinite subject.
Content 1: \gll ta-ndza | \gls AOR:3\flobv{}-eat | \glt `S/he/it ate it.'

Knowledge Point: Semi-objects (§\ref{sec:semi.object}), like objects, are interpreted as definite where non-overt, as shown by (\ref{ex:mWjpABJAt}) with the semi-transitive verb \japhug{βɟɤt}{obtain} (§\ref{sec:semi.transitive}, §\ref{sec:antipassive.t}).
Content 1: \gll tɕʰemɤpɯ nɯ kɯ ɲɤ́-wɣ-nɯsɯkʰo tɕe mɯ-pjɤ-βɟɤt. | \gls girl DEM ERG IFR-INV-rob LNK NEG-IFR-obtain | \glt `The girl had robbed him_i of it_j, he_i had not obtained it_j.'

Knowledge Point: Unlike core arguments, oblique arguments can be interpreted as indefinite when non-overt. For instance, when motion verbs like \japhug{ɕe}{go} and \japhug{ɣi}{come} (§\ref{sec:motion.verbs}), lack both an overt goal and a purposive clause (§\ref{sec:purposive.clause.motion.verbs}), two different meanings are possible. First, a previously mentioned goal can be understood as implicit as in (\ref{ex:qapri.tuCe}).
Content 1: \gll qapri tu-ɕe ri mɯ́j-cʰa tɕe | \gls snake IPFV:UP-go also NEG:SENS-can LNK | \glt `Snakes cannot go up (there in the chimney) either.'

Knowledge Point: Second, there is a minority\footnote{However, when the motion verb takes a supine purposive clause, the goal is very frequently non-overt and indefinite, as can be observed in the majority of the examples in §\ref{sec:purposive.clause.motion.verbs}. } of cases when no definite goal can be semantically recoverable, as in (\ref{ex:kuCe.nA.YWGi2}) where the two verbs \forme{ku-ɕe} and \forme{ɲɯ-ɣi} indicate back and forth distributed motion, without any clear direction.
Content 1: \gll ɯ-zda ɲɯ-ɕar ɲɯ-sɯsɤm tɕe tɕendɤre, ki kɯ-fse ku-ɕe nɤ ɲɯ-ɣi | \gls 3SG.POSS-companion IPFV-search SENS-think LNK LNK DEM INF:STAT-be.like IPFV:EAST-go ADD IPFV:west-come | \glt [That ant] wants to search for its companion, and goes here and fro like that.'

Knowledge Point: For instance, the indirective collocation \forme{tɯdi+lɤt} `shoot an arrow', which selects an oblique argument (goal) in \forme{ɯ-taʁ} (§\ref{sec:WtaR}, see \ref{ex:kW.WtaR.object} above in §\ref{sec:indirective.word.order}), lacks an overt oblique in (\ref{ex:non.overt.WtaR.kolAt}). In this example, it is clear that the subject must have aimed before shooting, and therefore that a covert definite oblique is implied, as confirmed by the choice of a specific orientation `towards east' rather than the indefinite orientation preverb.

The absence of relator nominal clause in \forme{ɯ-taʁ} in this example is to be interpreted here as absence of goal.

Knowledge Point: In (\ref{ex:non.overt.dat.toti}), the verb of speech \japhug{ti}{say} lacks an overt dative argument (§\ref{sec:dative}), and it is obvious in this context not only that there is no definite addressee, but that there is no addressee at all, since \forme{ti} here means `utter (a sound)'.

Knowledge Point: In other collocations, both the noun and the verb are orphan forms. For instance, \japhug{tʰaʁ+tɕʰot}{take a decision} was borrowed from the locution \tibet{ཐག་ཆོད་}{tʰag.tɕʰod}{be decided}, built from the noun \tibet{ཐག་པ་}{tʰag.pa}{rope} and the intransitive verb \tibet{ཆོད་}{tɕʰod}{be cut off}, neither of which are attested as independent words into Japhug. It does not take complement clause, and is better translated as `take a decision' rather than `decide'. The verbal element \forme{tɕʰot} is transitive (unlike Tibetan \tibet{ཆོད་}{tɕʰod}{be cut off}), and the person making the decision is indexed as subject (\ref{ex:thaR.pWtChota}).

Knowledge Point: The copulas are a distinct subclass of semi-transitive verbs (§\ref{sec:semi.transitive}), whose semi-object is the nominal predicate. There are two assertive copulas, the neutral \japhug{ŋu}{be} and the emphatic affirmative \japhug{ɕti}{be}, and one suppletive negative copula \japhug{maʁ}{not be} (§\ref{sec:suppletive.negative}). The emphatic affirmative copula occurs in particular to express contrast, as in (\ref{ex:Ctia.ma.maRa}).
Content 1: \gll aʑo βʑɯ ɕti-a ma, nɤki, pɣa maʁ-a | \gls 1SG mouse be.AFF:FACT LNK FILLER bird not.be:FACT | \glt `(The bat said:) I am a mouse, not a bird.'

Knowledge Point: The copulas cannot be used with inchoative meanings (`become') in the Aorist (§\ref{sec:aor.inchoative}) or the Inferential (§\ref{sec:ifr.inchoative}) unlike other stative verbs. The Aorist of the copulas are only attested to fix a point of temporal reference (§\ref{sec:temporal.reference}) and in periphrastic tenses (examples \ref{ex:tWwGCaB.tANu} in §\ref{sec:proximative.periphrastic} and \ref{ex:tAcha.tANu} in §\ref{sec:prerequisite.clause}). The lexicalized passives \forme{apa} and \forme{aβzu} (§\ref{sec:passive.lexicalized}) replace the copula to express inchoative meaning, as shown by (\ref{ex:ki.kWfse.naBzua}).

Knowledge Point: There are two main possessive constructions in Japhug. In the first one, illustrated by (\ref{ex:amkWm.tu}), the possessum is the intransitive subject of an existential verb (§\ref{sec:existential.basic}) and the possessor is indicated by a possessive prefix on the possessum (§\ref{ex:prefix.expression.of.possession}) and (optionally) a genitive phrase (example \ref{ex:11.Zo.pjAtunW} below, §\ref{sec:gen.possession}). In the second one (\ref{ex:tamkWm.aroa}), involving the semi-transitive verb \japhug{aro}{own} (§\ref{sec:semi.transitive}), the possessor is subject, and the possessum semi-object (§\ref{sec:semi.object}); when the possessum is an inalienably possessed noun (§\ref{sec:inalienably.possessed}), it selects the indefinite possessor prefix.

Knowledge Point: The mihi est-type construction in (\ref{ex:amkWm.tu}) is by far the most frequent one. It differs from the usual existential construction in that the number of the possessum (intransitive subject) is never indexed on the verb: in (\ref{ex:11.Zo.pjAtunW}) for instance, the subject \forme{ɯ-tɕɯ} takes the numeral \japhug{sqaptɯɣ}{eleven} but the existential verb \forme{pjɤ-tu} lacks plural indexation. Although number indexation in the existential construction is optional (§\ref{sec:existential.basic}, §\ref{sec:optional.indexation}), its presence is however more common than its absence. The non-indexation in (\ref{ex:11.Zo.pjAtunW}) is thus indicative of a significant syntactic difference between the existential and the possessive constructions, despite superficial similarity.

Knowledge Point: The pre-copula constituents (\forme{nɯtɕu ɕe-a} and \forme{pe ntsɯ}) cannot be analyzed as finite relative clauses (§\ref{sec:finite.relatives}), since this type of relatives are restricted to relativizing objects (§\ref{sec:object.relativization}) and goals, and are thus not attested with most intransitive verbs, whereas the postverbal copula constructions are found with all intransitive verbs without restriction. In this hypothesis, example (\ref{ex:nWtCu.Ce.Nu}) would literally be `it is (the fact that) I am going there', and (\ref{ex:pe.ntsW.Cti}) `it is that it is always good'.

Content 1: \gll tɕe jinde aj pɯ-mto-t-a me ri, pɯ-kɯ-xtɕi tɕe pɯ́-wɣ-mto | \gls LNK nowadays 1SG AOR-see-PST:TR-1SG LNK not.exist:FACT AOR-GENR:S/O-be.small LNK AOR-INV-see | \glt `I have not seen any [wild crane] recently, but when we were young, we did see (some).'

Knowledge Point: The scope of the negation is however not necessarily restricted to the object. In (\ref{ex:jinW.maNe}) for instance, the non-overt object anaphorically refers to \japhug{jima}{maize} mentioned in the previous sentences, but the scope of negation is rather on the essive participial clause \forme{ʑara nɯ-kɤ-nɯ-ndza} `as food for themselves/for themselves to eat' (§\ref{sec:essive.abs}): the villagers do plant maize, but for a different purpose.
Content 1: \gll tɕe ʑara nɯ-kɤ-nɯ-ndza tɕe koŋla ji-nɯ maŋe woma | \gls LNK 3PL 2PL.POSS-OBJ:PCP-AUTO-eat LNK completely plant:FACT-PL not.exist:SENS SFP | \glt `They don't plant any [maize] for themselves to eat, (they plant it to feed their pigs).'

Knowledge Point: With intransitive verbs, this construction is used to indicate the complete absence of the action `not ... at all' (\ref{ex:WNgW.ri.karia.me}).
Content 1: \gll tɯ-ci ɯ-rkɯ zɯ ku-rɤʑi-a tɕe nɯre ri ku-nɯ-tsʰi-a ɕti ma ɯ-ŋgɯ ri kɤ-ari-a me, ɕ-tu-nɤŋkɯŋke-a ri me | \gls INDEF.POSS-water 3SG.POSS-side LOC IPFV-stay-1SG LNK DEM:LOC LOC IPFV-AUTO-drink-1SG be.AFF:FACT LNK 3SG.POSS-in also AOR:EAST-go[II]-1SG not.exist:FACT TRAL-IPFV-DISTR:walk-1SG also not.exist:FACT | \glt `I am staying near the water and drinking (water) there, I did not go into the water at all, I am not walking around in it.'

Knowledge Point: The intransitive stative verb \japhug{sna}{be good, be worthy} (§\ref{sec:mna.sna}) is commonly used with negative existential verbs, with the meaning `not good for anything', as in (\ref{ex:sna.me}). The scope of universal negation in this case is on the essive adjunct (for instance \forme{nɯŋa ɯ-ndza} `cow fodder' in the first clause of \ref{ex:sna.me}).
Content 1: \gll nɯŋa ɯ-ndza sna ma nɯ ma sna me | \gls cow 3SG.POSS-food be.good:FACT LNK DEM apart.from be.good:FACT not.exist:FACT | \glt `[Oat] is good as fodder for cattle, but apart from that it is not good for anything.'
Content 2: \gll nɯŋa ɯ-ndza sna ma nɯ ma sna me | \gls cow 3SG.POSS-food be.good:FACT LNK DEM apart.from be.good:FACT not.exist:FACT | \glt `[Oat] is good as fodder for cattle, but apart from that it is not good for anything.'

Knowledge Point: The clause preceding the negative existential verb can be embedded within a participial clause with the existential verb \forme{kɯ-tu}, as in (\ref{ex:CtAnWtWta.kWtu.me}). A similar use of \forme{kɯ-tu} is also found in the possessive construction (example \ref{ex:Wmdzu.kWtu.me}, §\ref{sec:possessive.constructions}).
Content 1: \gll [[aʑo joβ tɕi ɕ-tɤ-nɯ-tɯt-a] kɯ-tu] me qʰe [aʑo ndɤre ɲɯ-ɤβzu-a ri kɯ-ra] me qʰe, nɤ-rcɯ\redp{}rca ʑo ɣi-a ŋu ma nɯ ma [[aʑɯɣ kɯ-ra] kɯ-tu] me | \gls 1SG INTERJ also TRAL-AOR-AUTO-say[II]-1SG SBJ:PCP-exist not.exist:FACT LNK 1SG ADVERS IPFV-become-1SG also SBJ:PCP-be.needed not.exist:FACT LNK 2SG.POSS-EMPH\redp{}together.with EMPH come:FACT-1SG be:FACT LNK DEM apart.from 1SG:GEN SBJ:PCP-be.needed SBJ:PCP-exist not.exist:FACT | \glt `I did not go and heed [the girl who was calling us], and I don't need to become anything special, I don't need anything, apart from following you.'
Content 2: \gll ɯ-ru nɯnɯ, kɯ-mpɕɯ\redp{}mpɕu ʑo ŋu, [ɯ-mdzu ri kɯ-tu] me | \gls 3SG.POSS-stalk DEM SBJ:PCP-EMPH\redp{}be.smooth EMPH be:FACT 3SG.POSS-thorn also SBJ:PCP-exist not.exist:FACT | \glt `Its stalk, it is very smooth, and it does not have any thorns.'

Knowledge Point: The postverbal negative existential verb can be combined with a verb taking the negative prefix, forming a double negation (§\ref{sec:double.negation}) expressing universal quantification (\ref{ex:mAnAmandZi.me}).
Content 1: \gll kɯ-ŋɤn mɤ-nɤma-ndʑi maka me | \gls SBJ:PCP-be.evil NEG-do:FACT-DU at.all not.exist:FACT | \glt `There is no evil thing that they do not do/They do all kinds of evil things.'

Knowledge Point: Copulas are exceptional in being the only verbs that can be repeated to express emphasis. This usage is only found in the traditional story register, as in (\ref{ex:tWNu.tWNu}). This construction differs from partial reduplication, which only targets one syllable (§\ref{sec:partial.redp}).
Content 1: \gll nɯ kɯ-fse ci tɯ-ŋu, nɯ mɤ-kɯ-naχtɕɯɣ ci \textbf{tɯ-ŋu} \textbf{tɯ-ŋu} | \gls DEM SBJ:PCP-be.like INDEF 2-be:FACT DEM NEG-SBJ:PCP-be.the.same INDEF 2-be:FACT 2-be:FACT | \glt `You are (someone) like that, you are different (from normal people).'

Knowledge Point: Existential verbs can also occur with the adverb \japhug{jamar}{about} to build an equative construction `as big as X' (§\ref{sec:sthWci.equative}) as in (\ref{ex:ajaR.ki.jamar.GAZu}).
Content 1: \gll ki aʑo a-jaʁ ki jamar ɣɤʑu. | \gls DEM.PROX 1SG 1SG.POSS-hand DEM.PROX about exist:SENS | \glt `The wild yak horn is about as big as my hand here.'
